annotatable.p: In a seminal work on student experience in higher education, Pascarella " Terenzini explored the variety of aspects that affect student experience [5]. Some of these are directly related to learning and teaching, others have to do with the life beyond class. All of these affect the way students experience learning and influence their level of satisfaction.

However, the concept of student experience is problematic.
Despite being discussed as a notion since the 30s by Dewey [6], the formal reference to student experience received a new thrust relatively recently and the focus is a more holistic representation of what it means for a student to be a student and the experience associated with earning a university qualification.

The idea that being at university is not only limited to teaching and it is not just about transmitting or receiving information are straightforward. It is also a fact that students are paying larger fees, while their experience of education in a rapidly changing environment. The massification of the HE sector (i.e. large increase in student numbers, lowering of entry level/grades, internationalization, blended and distance education) also contributed to the change of focus to considering students like consumers, and as a result, triggered the need to extend the collection of feedback beyond the satisfaction with teaching.
Firstly, the idea of student in a MOOC in the tranditional sense present major issues:

ul.li: participants (in most cases) do not pay to enrol
participants might not intend to follow the MOOC from start to finish
participants may not want to complete assessment
there are many assumptions about the target audience and level of the material

annotatable.p: Secondly, defining the idea of experience presents some difficulty as the terms used to refer to the experience in the literature are far from clear.
In the short survey at the beginning of the paper we asked you to define for key terms: 1) student experience; 2) student engagement; 3) student satisfaction; and 4) student evaluation of teaching.
